channel.title: De-centralized quick downloads (BitTorrent or gnutella?)
channel.description:
I'm trying to figure out a better way to distribute semi-large (16-100mb) files to a large number of people running a java program than HTTP downloads that are bandwidth heavy and hammer the server. I haven't found a recent [url=http://www.threerings.net/code/snark/]java torrent implementation[/url], so I was thinking about writing a wrapper for [url=http://www.rasterbar.com/products/libtorrent/]libtorrent[/url], and I found that frostwire actually already has such a wrapper, I'm currently downloading the frostwire source which is massive. But that got me thinking about gnutella, it's in frostwire too and potentially another good candidate.
Do any of you have experience with either of the above, from a programming point of view? Or do you know any nice, easy, recent pure-java implementations of either protocol? Or do you have a better alternative? Thanks.

item.title: De-centralized quick downloads (BitTorrent or gnutella?)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Can someone test a command line windows binary for me? I’ve attached it to this post, see if it runs, it should display the ‘help’ dialog at the very least, and if you could test it to see if it will start downloading a magnet link for you I’d appreciate it.

I really don’t know what’s going on, because it seems to run just fine under Linux using WINE, but when I run it on Windows (XP and 7) it doesn’t seem to do anything, no errors, no output. I don’t know quite what is going on. I cross compiled it myself under Linux using mingw32.

Read full topic

item.title: De-centralized quick downloads (BitTorrent or gnutella?)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I still haven’t found a GOOD way to handle this, but I think what I might do is compile a transmission-cli binary for all the targets (32-bit windows and linux, and ppc and intel OSX), and then invoke the process from java and parse the output. It’s nasty, but not more nasty than using JNI, which would require a 32-bit and 64-bit shared library for windows and linux, and one each for OSX as well, uck.

I’d love other and/or better ideas from anyone, please.

Read full topic

item.title: De-centralized quick downloads (BitTorrent or gnutella?)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

sanga282:

why does it have to be done in java? you could set up your own tracker with ease and then just get people to connect using torrent clients to that for your files

Mopman:

data files for a wellknown java application on these boards, at a guess

That is the right answer, it’s for 16-100mb cache files for various versions of an application.

Read full topic

item.title: De-centralized quick downloads (BitTorrent or gnutella?)
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Ollie:

When I asked for you I was told that snark is quite good, and in regards to gnutella, Phex.

I actually found both of these yesterday, phex does look quite good and it might work for what I need, but it looks closely tied to the GUI and I’m not sure how easy ripping out the bare minimum would be. snark looks like it could have been good last time it was updated back in 2003, but now it is missing so many needed things like DHT, encryption, magnet links, HTTP seeding, etc etc that it is near useless as a torrent client. If I used snark I would have to rely on a central tracker staying up for it to work, but if I use a recent client I don’t.

Read full topic

item.title: De-centralized quick downloads (BitTorrent or gnutella?)
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:3, topic:373091”]When I asked for you I was told that snark is quite good, and in regards to gnutella, Phex.

With that said, you’d obviously need to have a ceiling upload limit. I don’t know how you could go about determining this though.

Why would he need to restrict the upload limit? Just have an option for users to disable uploading.[/quote]
That would be ideal, but do you believe that the users would continue to share the files?

Read full topic

item.title: De-centralized quick downloads (BitTorrent or gnutella?)
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

When I asked for you I was told that snark is quite good, and in regards to gnutella, Phex.

Lothy:

With that said, you’d obviously need to have a ceiling upload limit. I don’t know how you could go about determining this though.

Why would he need to restrict the upload limit? Just have an option for users to disable uploading.

Read full topic

item.title: De-centralized quick downloads (BitTorrent or gnutella?)
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I’m not sure it would really matter which method of distribution you use, presuming they’re quite similar. I don’t know much about gnutella, but I’m assuming it works in a similar fashion.

With that said, you’d obviously need to have a ceiling upload limit. I don’t know how you could go about determining this though.

Read full topic
